name: Straw Man
description: Misrepresenting someone's argument to make it easier to attack.
example: Person A: We should have better school lunches. Person B: My opponent wants to ban all snacks.
correctedExample: Person B: I agree we need better school lunches. Let’s discuss how to improve them while keeping some snack options.
explanation: Person B twisted Person A's argument into something extreme and easier to criticize.

name: Ad Hominem
description: Attacking the person instead of their argument.
example: Don't listen to her ideas about climate change—she’s not even a scientist.
correctedExample: Her background may not be scientific, but we can still evaluate her argument on its own.
explanation: The speaker ignores the actual argument and attacks the person instead.

name: Appeal to Popularity
description: Saying something is true just because many people believe it.
example: Everyone says this diet works, so it must be the best.
correctedExample: We should look at scientific studies to see if the diet is effective.
explanation: Popularity doesn’t guarantee truth or effectiveness.

name: False Dilemma
description: Presenting only two options when more exist.
example: You’re either with us or against us.
correctedExample: You can support parts of our idea without agreeing with everything.
explanation: This limits complex situations to just two choices unfairly.

name: Slippery Slope
description: Claiming one small step will lead to a terrible outcome.
example: If we allow kids to choose dinner, soon they'll make all the decisions at home.
correctedExample: Letting kids choose dinner doesn’t mean they’ll control everything else.
explanation: The argument exaggerates the consequences without proof.

name: Circular Reasoning
description: Using the conclusion as a premise.
example: I’m trustworthy because I always tell the truth.
correctedExample: You can trust me because I’ve always been honest in past situations.
explanation: The reasoning goes in a loop without offering real evidence.

name: Hasty Generalization
description: Making a broad claim based on little evidence.
example: I met two rude tourists from that country—everyone from there must be rude.
correctedExample: It’s unfair to judge a whole country based on two people.
explanation: The argument generalizes from a very small sample.

name: Post Hoc
description: Assuming one event caused another just because it happened first.
example: I wore my lucky socks and we won—must be the socks!
correctedExample: Winning was probably due to skill, not my socks.
explanation: Correlation doesn't mean causation.

name: Appeal to Emotion
description: Using emotions instead of facts to make an argument.
example: If you don’t donate, these puppies will suffer.
correctedExample: Your donation helps animals get care. Here’s how it works.
explanation: The argument tries to persuade with guilt instead of reasons.

name: Red Herring
description: Introducing something unrelated to distract from the topic.
example: Why worry about pollution when we haven’t solved poverty yet?
correctedExample: We can care about both pollution and poverty. Let’s discuss this issue now.
explanation: The speaker changes the subject to avoid the original issue.

name: Bandwagon
description: Arguing something is right because everyone is doing it.
example: Everyone is investing in this app—you should too!
correctedExample: Let’s evaluate whether this app is a smart investment.
explanation: The argument relies on group behavior, not reason.

name: Appeal to Authority
description: Believing a claim is true just because an authority says so.
example: This celebrity says it works, so it must be good.
correctedExample: Let’s look at evidence or expert research instead of just taking their word for it.
explanation: The person may not be qualified to speak on the topic.

name: Begging the Question
description: Assuming what you're trying to prove.
example: Stealing is wrong because it’s illegal.
correctedExample: Stealing is wrong because it harms others and takes away what isn't yours.
explanation: The argument assumes the conclusion instead of proving it.

name: False Cause
description: Assuming a wrong cause-effect relationship.
example: Sales dropped after the new logo—we need to change it back.
correctedExample: Let’s examine other factors that may have affected sales.
explanation: Timing alone doesn’t prove the logo caused the problem.

name: No True Scotsman
description: Changing a definition to protect a generalization from criticism.
example: No real artist would sell their work. Oh, she did? Then she’s not a real artist.
correctedExample: Let’s not exclude people just because they don’t fit a narrow view.
explanation: The claim redefines 'real artist' to ignore counterexamples.

name: Loaded Question
description: Asking a question with an assumption built in.
example: Why are you always so lazy at work?
correctedExample: How do you manage your workload throughout the day?
explanation: The question assumes laziness without evidence.

name: Tu Quoque
description: Avoiding criticism by pointing out the critic’s behavior.
example: You smoke too, so don’t tell me to quit.
correctedExample: Even if I smoke, that doesn’t mean smoking is safe.
explanation: It shifts focus from the argument to the person.

name: Appeal to Nature
description: Assuming something is good because it’s natural.
example: It’s all-natural, so it must be healthy.
correctedExample: Let’s check if it’s actually healthy, not just ‘natural’.
explanation: Natural things can be harmful too.

name: Middle Ground
description: Assuming the compromise between two sides is always right.
example: One person says 2+2=4, another says it’s 6—so it must be 5.
correctedExample: Let’s check the math instead of averaging opinions.
explanation: The truth isn’t always between two opinions.

name: False Analogy
description: Comparing two things that aren’t truly alike.
example: Employees are like nails. Just hit them to make them work.
correctedExample: Employees are people and should be motivated with respect, not force.
explanation: The comparison is misleading and ignores key differences.
